writing_prompt: When Arthur stumbles upon the scars Merlin has been hiding, he demands answers—but the truth behind them reveals more than either of them expected, leaving their bond forever changed.
story:
It was a crisp autumn morning in Camelot, with a chill in the air that hinted at the changing seasons. Arthur, clad in his usual finery, strode into the courtyard, his boots clicking on the stone flags. Merlin, busy gathering a basket of herbs for Gaius, looked up to find the Prince's piercing gaze fixed on him.

Their eyes met, and for a moment, time seemed to freeze. Then, Arthur's gaze dropped to Merlin's left arm, where a series of scars ran in a jagged line from elbow to wrist.

Merlin's heart sank. He had hoped to keep his secret hidden forever.

'What... happened?' Arthur's voice was low, his tone a mixture of concern and curiosity.

Merlin's instincts screamed at him to deny everything, to claim it was just a silly accident. But something about Arthur's expression stayed his tongue. Maybe it was the genuine concern etched on his face, or perhaps it was the way his eyes seemed to bore into Merlin's very soul.

Whatever the reason, Merlin found himself taking a deep breath and speaking the truth.

'It's... from my past,' he said, his voice barely above a whisper. 'I was a... a slave, in a different life. They... they marked me with a brand, as a warning to others.'

Arthur's eyes widened, his face pale. 'A brand? What kind of brand?'

Merlin hesitated, unsure how much to reveal. But something about Arthur's open expression put him at ease.

'It was a... a symbol, of sorts. A warning to anyone who saw it that I was... property. Not human.'

The words hung in the air, and for a moment, Arthur said nothing. Then, his face twisted in a mixture of anger and disgust.

'Who did this to you?' he growled, his fists clenched at his sides.

Merlin's heart skipped a beat. He had expected Arthur to be shocked, or even horrified. But this... this was something more.

'You don't have to know,' Merlin said hastily, taking a step back. 'It's not important.'

But Arthur's eyes were fixed on him, burning with a fierce intensity.

'I want to know,' he said, his voice low and even. 'I want to know who hurt you, and why.'

Merlin's instincts screamed at him to run, to escape the Prince's prying eyes. But something about Arthur's expression stayed him. Maybe it was the way he looked at him, like Merlin was the most precious thing in the world.

Or maybe it was the way Arthur's eyes seemed to see right through him, to the very heart of the matter.

Whatever the reason, Merlin found himself taking a deep breath, and speaking the truth.

'It was... a man, named Gorvoth. He was a... a slave trader, and he sold me to a wealthy merchant in the north. I was... I was used as a plaything, for months. They... they marked me with the brand, to remind me of my place.'

Arthur's face twisted in a mixture of rage and sorrow. He looked like he wanted to punch something, or cry.

'I'm so sorry, Merlin,' he said, his voice barely above a whisper. 'I had no idea.'

Merlin shrugged, feeling a weight lift off his shoulders. 'It's not your fault,' he said. 'It's just... it's just part of who I am, now.'

But Arthur's eyes seemed to see right through him, to the very heart of the matter.

'No, it's not just part of who you are,' he said, his voice firm. 'It's a part of your history, yes. But it doesn't define you. You're so much more than that.'

Merlin's heart skipped a beat. No one had ever looked at him like that before. Like he was... worthy.

'You're... you're not just a servant, or a wizard,' Arthur said, his voice filled with conviction. 'You're a person, Merlin. A person with scars, and fears, and dreams. And I want to help you heal, to help you find your way.'

Merlin's eyes welled up with tears. No one had ever offered him such kindness before. Such understanding.

'Arthur,' he whispered, his voice barely audible.

But Arthur just smiled, his eyes shining with a warmth that made Merlin's heart melt.

'I'm here for you, Merlin,' he said. 'Always.'

As the sun rose higher in the sky, casting a golden glow over the courtyard, Merlin felt a weight lift off his shoulders. He felt seen, for the first time in his life.

And in that moment, he knew that he would never be alone again. That Arthur would always be there to help him heal, to help him find his way.

Their bond had changed, forever. And Merlin knew that he would never be the same again.

writing_prompt: A scruffy young raven, outcast by her kin, takes up residence in your chambers, much to the dismay of your court. But as the bird grows into a striking and mischievous companion, you realize she may be more than just a pet—she's family.
story:
Ravens and Royalty

As the sun dipped below the walls of Lake-town, casting a warm orange glow across the water, I stood at the edge of my chambers, observing the commotion that had erupted within. A fluttering black shape swooped in through the open window, and my courtiers, nobles, and guards alike took up the cry. "The King's chambers are being overrun by a pest!" one of them shouted. "Get it out, get it out!"

I watched with amusement as they flailed about, trying to shoo away the raven, which had settled itself on a nearby shelf, regarding them with a sharp, black eye. I smiled, remembering the countless times I'd seen my own kin treat the birds with disdain. It seemed I was developing a taste for contrarian behavior.

The bird, who had apparently chosen to make itself at home in my chambers, let out a soft caw and nudged a nearby vial of ink with its beak, sending it rolling onto the floor. I winced as the ink spilled across the expensive rug, but my courtiers were too busy trying to catch the bird to notice. I chuckled, deciding to let the bird have its way.

Over the next few days, the raven, whom I'd named Midnight, became a fixture in my chambers. It would perch on my shoulder or swoop in to steal bits of food from my plate, much to the dismay of my courtiers. They would whisper among themselves, speaking of the "pest" that had taken up residence in the King's chambers, but I simply smiled and waved them off.

As the days turned into weeks, I began to notice changes in Midnight. It grew more confident, more curious, and more playful. It would mimic the sounds of the townspeople, much to my amusement, and even learned to recognize my own name. I found myself looking forward to its visits, and before I knew it, I'd grown accustomed to having Midnight by my side.

One evening, as I sat at my desk, quill in hand, Midnight settled onto my shoulder, nudging my ear with its beak. I reached up to stroke its feathers, feeling a sense of peace wash over me. It was then that I realized I'd grown attached to the bird. Not just as a pet, but as a companion.

As the months passed, my courtiers began to notice the change in me. They'd see me laughing with Midnight, or scolding it gently when it got into mischief. They'd hear me talking to it, as if it were a person, and they'd exchange worried glances. But I didn't care. Midnight had become a part of my life, and I wouldn't trade it for anything.

It was during one of these moments, when I was sitting with Midnight on my lap, that I received an unexpected visitor. Thorin Oakenshield, the renowned Dwarf warrior, stood in the doorway, his eyes fixed on Midnight with a mixture of curiosity and wariness.

"Your Majesty," he said, bowing low. "I've come to discuss the matters of the realm."

I gestured for him to sit, and as he did, Midnight hopped off my lap and perched on the back of his chair, regarding him with a piercing gaze. Thorin's eyes widened in surprise, and he reached out a hand, hesitantly, as if to touch the bird's feathers.

"You've taken a liking to the raven, I see," he said, his voice filled with a hint of wonder.

I nodded, smiling. "Midnight's become a part of my family, Thorin. I'm not sure I could ever get rid of it."

Thorin's expression softened, and he reached out to gently stroke Midnight's feathers. "I think I understand," he said. "Sometimes, the things that bring us the most joy are the ones we least expect."

As we spoke, I realized that Thorin was right. Midnight had brought a sense of joy and companionship into my life, and I couldn't imagine living without it. It was more than just a pet, more than just a bird – it was family.

And as I looked at Thorin, I saw something there that I hadn't seen before. A spark of recognition, a sense of understanding. He, too, knew what it was like to be an outcast, to be seen as different.

"Thorin," I said, my voice low and serious. "I think we have more in common than you might think."

He looked at me, his eyes narrowing in surprise, and for a moment, I thought I saw something there, something that went beyond mere friendship or camaraderie.

But it was just a fleeting glimpse, and when I looked again, it was gone.

Still, I knew that I'd seen something there, something that hinted at a deeper connection between us. And as I looked at Midnight, perched on Thorin's shoulder, I knew that I had to explore this feeling further.

For the first time in a long time, I felt a sense of hope, a sense of possibility. Maybe, just maybe, I'd found a true friend in Thorin Oakenshield. And maybe, just maybe, I'd found something more.

As the sun dipped below the horizon, casting the room in a warm, golden light, I smiled to myself, feeling a sense of peace wash over me. I had Midnight, my loyal and mischievous companion, and I had Thorin, my fellow outcast, my friend.

And who knows? Maybe, just maybe, we'd find something more, something that would change our lives forever.

writing_prompt: On the coldest night of the year, Merlin braves the frost to gather a rare herb, only to find himself summoned to Arthur's chambers. What begins as a simple scolding over his lack of winter gear turns into an unexpectedly tender moment by the fire.
story:
The air was biting, the frost crunching beneath Merlin's boots as he trudged through the castle's gardens. It was the coldest night of the year, the wind howling through the trees like a pack of wolves. He huddled deeper into his cloak, his breath misting in front of him as he searched for the elusive Winter's Tear.

It was said to bloom only once a year, its delicate petals opening for a single night before wilting in the morning's first light. Gaius had been after him for weeks to find a specimen, and Merlin had finally managed to track it down. He spotted the plant's pale flowers glowing like lanterns in the dark, and his heart swelled with a mix of excitement and relief.

Merlin knelt down beside the plant, his fingers closing gently around the stem as he plucked the flower free. It felt fragile in his hand, its petals unfolding like a tiny star as he held it up to the moonlight. He tucked it into the pouch at his belt, feeling a sense of satisfaction wash over him. This would keep Gaius happy, at least.

As he stood up to make his way back to the castle, Merlin noticed a figure standing in the shadows. He hesitated, his hand on the pouch containing the precious herb, before realizing it was Arthur. The prince was wrapped in a heavy cloak, his face pinched with cold as he watched Merlin with a critical eye.

"What are you doing out here, Merlin?" Arthur's voice was low and even, but Merlin could sense a thread of annoyance running beneath the surface.

Merlin held up his hands, feeling a flush rise to his cheeks. "I was just – "

"You're not even wearing gloves," Arthur interrupted, his gaze dropping to Merlin's bare hands. "You're going to catch your death out here."

Merlin shrugged, feeling a twinge of embarrassment. "I didn't think it would get this cold."

Arthur's expression softened slightly, and he stepped forward, his movements fluid despite the cold. "Come inside, Merlin. You can't stay out here all night."

Merlin hesitated, unsure if he should leave the precious herb unattended. But Arthur's words were laced with a hint of genuine concern, and he found himself following the prince back to the castle.

As they walked, the castle's lights grew brighter, casting a warm glow over the frost-covered gardens. Merlin felt a sense of relief wash over him, his fingers aching with cold as he followed Arthur into the warmth of the castle.

They walked in silence, the only sound the soft crunch of their boots on the stone floor. Merlin felt a sense of unease growing inside him, unsure what to expect from Arthur's chambers. But the prince led him straight to the fire, where a steaming cup of tea waited on a nearby tray.

Arthur gestured for Merlin to sit, his eyes never leaving the young warlock's face. "You're not taking care of yourself, Merlin. You need to be more careful."

Merlin felt a surge of defensiveness rise up inside him, but something about Arthur's expression stayed his tongue. Maybe it was the genuine concern etched on the prince's face, or maybe it was the warmth of the fire that seemed to seep into his bones. Whatever the reason, Merlin found himself sitting down, his eyes fixed on the flames as Arthur poured him a cup of tea.

As they sat there in silence, Merlin felt a sense of calm wash over him. It was a strange, quiet moment, one that seemed to exist outside the normal rhythms of their relationship. Arthur's words had been a scolding, but there was something beneath them that felt almost...tender.

Merlin glanced up to find Arthur watching him, his eyes warm and gentle in the firelight. For a moment, they just sat there, the only sound the crackle of the flames and the soft hum of the wind outside.

It was a small, fleeting moment, one that Merlin felt like he'd stumbled into by accident. But as he looked into Arthur's eyes, he felt a sense of connection that went beyond their normal dynamic. It was a moment of understanding, of empathy, and of something deeper.

As the fire crackled on, Merlin felt a sense of peace settle over him. Maybe it was the warmth of the flames, or maybe it was the kindness in Arthur's eyes. Whatever the reason, Merlin felt a sense of belonging, of being seen and understood in a way that felt almost...magical.

And as he sat there, sipping his tea and watching the flames dance, Merlin felt a sense of wonder that he'd never felt before. It was a small, quiet moment, but one that felt like it could change everything.

As the night wore on, Merlin found himself feeling more and more at ease. The fire crackled on, casting a warm glow over the room as he sat there with Arthur. It was a moment of perfect peace, one that felt like it could last forever.

And as the night drew to a close, Merlin felt a sense of gratitude towards Arthur. Maybe it was the prince's words, or maybe it was the warmth of the fire. Whatever the reason, Merlin felt a sense of connection that he'd never felt before.

As he stood up to leave, Arthur's hand closed around his arm, his touch warm and gentle. "Be more careful, Merlin," he said, his voice low and even.

Merlin nodded, feeling a sense of understanding wash over him. "I will, Arthur. I promise."

Arthur's eyes locked onto his, and for a moment, they just stared at each other. It was a small, quiet moment, but one that felt like it could change everything.

As Merlin made his way back to his room, the fire still crackling in his mind, he felt a sense of peace settle over him. Maybe it was the warmth of the flames, or maybe it was the kindness in Arthur's eyes. Whatever the reason, Merlin felt a sense of belonging, of being seen and understood in a way that felt almost...magical.

And as he drifted off to sleep, the Winter's Tear safe in his pouch, Merlin felt a sense of wonder that he'd never felt before. It was a small, quiet moment, but one that felt like it could change everything.

writing_prompt: When Bilbo Baggins left the Shire for his grand adventure, Lobelia Sackville-Baggins saw an opportunity to claim Bag End for herself. But when news of Bilbo's unexpected fate reaches Hobbiton, her plans—and her pride—are thrown into chaos.
story:
The sun had barely set on Hobbiton, casting a warm orange glow over the thatched roofs and tidy gardens of the Shire's inhabitants. In the midst of this peaceful scene, a subtle undercurrent of tension simmered, particularly at Bag End, the grandest and most coveted residence in the village. For years, Lobelia Sackville-Baggins had harbored a deep-seated desire to claim the property for herself, and with Bilbo's departure on his grand adventure, she finally saw her chance.

As she strolled through the village, a sly smile played on her lips, her eyes scanning the familiar surroundings with a calculating gaze. She paused in front of Bag End, running a critical eye over the property. The garden, once Bilbo's pride and joy, was beginning to show signs of neglect, and the windows, though still spotless, seemed a trifle duller than they had in the past.

Lobelia's smile grew wider as she mentally inventoried the property's assets and liabilities. She knew the interior was still in good condition, thanks to Bilbo's fastidious nature, but she also knew that a few well-placed alterations could transform the space to suit her own tastes.

Just then, a group of hobbits strolled by, their faces flushed with excitement. "Did you hear the news, Lobelia?" asked one of them, a young hobbit named Percy. "Bilbo's been seen in the company of dwarves and elves, and they say he's discovered a treasure trove of gold and jewels!"

Lobelia's smile faltered for an instant, but she quickly regained her composure. "Ah, yes, I've heard rumors," she said airily. "But I'm sure it's all just a silly tale. Bilbo's always been a bit of a dreamer, after all."

As the group continued on their way, Lobelia's thoughts turned to the implications of Bilbo's success. If he returned to the Shire, he might well reclaim his property, and her plans would be foiled once again. But if he remained abroad, Bag End would be hers for the taking.

The days passed, and the news of Bilbo's adventures spread like wildfire through the Shire. Lobelia watched with growing unease as the villagers began to speculate about Bilbo's fate. Some said he'd been killed by goblins, while others claimed he'd discovered a magical elixir that granted him eternal youth.

As the weeks turned into months, Lobelia's anxiety gave way to a sense of hope. Perhaps, she thought, Bilbo would never return, and Bag End would be hers to keep. She began to make discreet inquiries about the property, inquiring about its value and potential for renovation.

But just as she was starting to make progress, a group of travelers arrived in Hobbiton, bearing news that would shake the very foundations of the Shire. Bilbo Baggins, it seemed, was not only alive but had also become a hero of the realm, celebrated for his bravery and cunning in the face of overwhelming odds.

Lobelia's world was turned upside down. Her plans, her pride, and her very sense of identity were all thrown into chaos. She felt like a leaf blown by the wind, helpless to control her fate.

As the villagers gathered to celebrate Bilbo's return, Lobelia stood at the edge of the crowd, her eyes fixed on the figure of her nemesis. She looked old and worn, her once-proud face now etched with lines of disappointment and defeat.

Bilbo, on the other hand, seemed younger and more vibrant than ever, his eyes shining with a newfound sense of purpose. As he made his way through the crowd, shaking hands and exchanging greetings, Lobelia felt a pang of sorrow. She had lost, and she knew that she would never be able to reclaim Bag End.

As the celebration drew to a close, Bilbo made his way to Bag End, where a warm welcome awaited him. Lobelia, meanwhile, slipped away into the shadows, her heart heavy with regret and her spirit bruised by defeat.

In the days that followed, Bilbo settled back into his life at Bag End, surrounded by the familiar comforts of his home. Lobelia, on the other hand, was forced to confront the reality of her own failure. She knew that she would never be able to claim Bag End, and that her own pride and ambition had been her downfall.

As the seasons passed, Lobelia's reputation in the Shire began to change. Once seen as a force to be reckoned with, she was now viewed as a relic of the past, a reminder of the dangers of pride and ambition. And as for Bag End, it remained the property of its rightful owner, Bilbo Baggins, a symbol of the enduring power of kindness, humility, and friendship.

In the end, it was not the treasure of gold and jewels that had changed Lobelia's life, but the discovery of her own limitations and the value of humility. And though she would never be able to claim Bag End, she knew that she had been given a second chance, a chance to start anew and to rediscover the joys of living in harmony with her fellow hobbits.
